remarks.para:
The syntax for the Tingen version number is "YY.MM<.patch>".
The version number is pulled from Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs.

This isn't 'Nam, there are rules:
The MM component is always two digits (ex: July would be "07")
If a release doesn't include a patch number, omit the <.patch> component.
The version number cannot exceed three components (example: "25.07.1")

For each release of Tingen the following lines:
[assembly: AssemblyVersion("#.#.#.#")] [assembly: AssemblyFileVersion("#.#.#.#")]
Need to be modified as so:
[assembly: AssemblyVersion("YY.MM.<.patch>.0")] [assembly: AssemblyFileVersion("YY.MM.<.patch>.0")]

TingenVersionNumber.example:
The December 2024 release would look like:
[assembly: AssemblyVersion("24.12.0.0")] [assembly: AssemblyFileVersion("24.12.0.0")]

remarks.para:
The syntax for the Tingen build number is "HHMM", and is set at runtime
via TingenSession.BuildStaticVars().
The build number is used in log files, and to help troubleshoot issues. For the
most part it's not visible to the user.

TingenBuildNumber.value: If Tingen is built at 10:30AM, the build number would be "1030"

remarks.para: There should only two methods in this class, both of which are required by Avatar:

This class doesn't do much actual work, and should remain fairly static. For the
most part, it just hands information to Outpost31, where the heavy lifting is done.

This method is required by Avatar and should not be modified.
The Tingen Version Number is kinda complex, so it might make sense to
read about it.

This method is required by Avatar and should not be modified.
The only difference between the development and stable versions of Tingen is that
the development version uses the"UAT" Avatar System Code, while the stable
version uses the "LIVE" Avatar System Code.
For the development/UAT version of Tingen, you will see the following line:
tnSession.AvData.SystemCode = "UAT";
And for the stable/LIVE version of Tingen, you will see the following line:
tnSession.AvData.SystemCode = "LIVE";
